mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Baronniesia delioti gen. n. sp. n., a new subterranean Leptodirini from the French Pyrenees (Coleoptera: Leiodidae: Cholevinae)

tax:treatment.tax:nomenclature: AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiagenusFresneda, Bourdeau & FailleBaronniesia Fresneda, Bourdeau & Faille gen. n.

tax:div.tax:p: Type species:AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiadeliotispeciesFresneda, Bourdeau & FailleBaronniesia delioti Fresneda, Bourdeau & Faille sp. n.

Description. Thetype species of this new genus is characterized by its large size, 4.0–5.0 mm long, being one of the largest species of Leptodirini known from the Pyrenean chain. Sexual dimorphism is very accentuated: male with dilated pentamerous protarsi, antennomeres5 to 9 exceptionally wide, forming a sort of blade (Fig.1), filiform in females (Fig.2). Elytra strongly punctured; punctures wide and rough, forming poorly defined transverse striae, especially in the front area. Mesoventral carina low, forming an obtuse angle, and not extended on metaventrite. Male genital segment reduced, forming a slightly sclerotized ring with two very long lateral appendices. Width of aedeagus (Fig.3) decreasing from base to apex in dorsal view, apex rounded with central part truncated; lateral margins sinuate; aedeagus slightly bent in lateral view (Fig.4), forming an obtuse angle; terminal tip strongly curved; basal part proportionally large. Lateral styles of aedeagus very thin through their entire length; apex simple, with only three spines (Fig.7). Inner sac of aedeagus with the three sections typical of theAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeSpeonomusgenusSpeonomus phyletic lineage (Fig.5) (Jeannel1910,Dupré1992,Fresneda1998,Fresneda & Salgado2000); reinforcement bands (BRA) only in apical area, very long and reaching the base of the section, which is round and more sclerotized, inserted on two additional large feather-like structures located at the external apical part of the FDM (Fig.5:BDAM). Median area with dorsal (Fig.5: FDM) and ventral feather-like structures (Fig.5: FVM), two additional slightly curved feather-like structures forming an inverted “V” located above FDM and FVM (Fig.5: IVP), betweenBDAM. Apical part of PY in basal area (Fig.5:FAPY), above connection nodule (NL), very thin and elongate; feather-like structures associated with PY with strongly sclerotized and large basal nodule; ventral basal complex very robust and sclerotized. Eighth female urosternite with short and robust apophyse and round apex (Fig.15). Spermatheca of “type1 ”sensuPerreau (1989) (Fig.16), thin and elongated, slightly curved and with two well-differentiated lobes; apical lobe spherical and smaller than basal lobe, with spermathecal gland inserted at the same place as spermiduct. Spermiduct10–12 times longer than spermatheca, which gets larger close to the insertion with spermatheca and crosses a sclerotized disc at the contact with bursa copulatrix. Main part of spermiduct close to spermatheca strongly curved.
Etymology. The name of the new genus refers to the mountainous massif of Baronnies, located north of the central Pyrenees, between the Aure valley and the Adour valley.

Taxonomic notes.AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiagenusBaronniesia belongs to the Infraflagellates of theAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeSpeonomusgenusSpeonomus “phyletic series” ofJeannel (1910). However, the new genus is morphologically very isolated from the rest of the Pyrenean fauna. At first glance, it looks like a largeAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeEuryspeonomusbreuilispeciesJeannel, 1919Euryspeonomus breuiliJeannel,1919 (Sierra de Aralar, Navarra,Spain) but an accurate examination shows that some genital structures are very different, and similar toAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharisgenusAbeilleAntrocharis Abeille de Perrin,1878 (Ariège,France) and related taxa. The lateral styles of the aedeagus ofAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiagenusBaronniesia are very thin through their entire length, with only three spines at the apex. The inner sac of the aedeagus has two additional feather-like structures forming an inverted “V” above the FDM and FVM, and the apical part of PY is very thin and elongate. All these characters allow to link the new genus to the Pyrenean genera of Leptodirini of theAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharisgenusAntrocharis group (sensuFresnedaet al.2007), which is redefined below.

tax:figure.tax:p: FIGURES 1–2. Habitus ofAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiadeliotispeciesBaronniesia delioti gen. n. sp. n. 1―male; 2―female.

tax:ref_group.tax:p: TheAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharisgenusAntrocharis group was characterized by the following characters (the terminology of the structures of the inner sac of the aedeagus followsJeannel1924,Bellés1984,Dupré1989,1992 andFresneda1998):

1) The median lobe of the aedeagus in lateral view is curved forming right or obtuse angle, with a strong depression or dorsal sinuosity in the apical third. Until now this character was considered a synapomorphy of the group. The median lobe of aedeagus ofAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiagenusBaronniesia in lateral view is curved forming an obtuse angle, but without any depression or sinuosity, decreasing regularly from base to apex, and strongly curved in the central part (Fig.4).

tax:div.tax:p: 2) Lateral styles of the aedeagus are shorter than the median lobe, very thin through their entire length and each carrying three long spines at the apex (one shorter), without any penicillum, cavity or membranous lamina (Figs.8–9). The lateral stylus ofAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiagenusBaronniesia conforms to this morphological structure (Fig.7).

3) Presence of two additional strongly sclerotized feather-like structures forming an inverted “V”, above the FDM and FVM (Figs.5–6: IVP). These two feather-like structures are present inAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiagenusBaronniesia, which also has two additional structures located laterally of the inverted “V” (Fig.5:BDAM).

4) The apical part of PY (FAPY), above the connection nodule (NL), is very thin and elongate.AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiagenusBaronniesia shares this character with all genera of theAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharisgenusAntrocharis group (Fig.5:FAPY). In all the other genera of the Pyrenean Leptodirini (not members of theAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharisgenusAntrocharis group) the apical part of PY is shorter, broader and conical.

tax:figure.tax:p: FIGURES 3–4. Aedeagus ofAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiadeliotispeciesBaronniesia delioti gen. n. sp. n. 3—dorsal view; 4—lateral view.

tax:ref_group.tax:p: TheAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharisgenusAntrocharis group includes four genera:AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharisgenusAntrocharis (two species),AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeGesciellagenusGiachino & Gueorguiev, 1989GesciellaGiachino & Guéorguiev,1989 (monospecific genus),AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeParatroglophyesgenusFoures, 1954ParatroglophyesFourès,1954 (two species) andAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesgenusAbeilleTroglophyes Abeille de Perrin,1894in pars sensuFresnedaet al.2007:AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesaubryispeciesCoiffait, 1953T. aubryiCoiffait,1953 with the subspeciesT. a. vallierensisCoiffait,1953 (Fresnedaet al.2007).Coiffait (1953) indicates that the two subspecies ofAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesaubryispeciesTroglophyes aubryi have the apex of the styles each with three spines and a penicillum composed of7–8 setae. We did not see a penicillum in the numerous specimens from the Anglade cave (locus typicus ofAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesaubryiaubryisubspeciesT. aubryi aubryi) and various MSS (“Milieu souterrain superficiel ”Juberthieet al.1980) in the area; all examined specimens have only three spines without penicillum (Fig.9).

AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeEskualdunelladelespierreispeciesCoiffait, 1950Eskualdunella delespierreiCoiffait,1950 b, an enigmatic species from the French Basque country, known by a single specimen, seems to have a similar structure of the stylus apex, as the members of theAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharisgenusAntrocharis group: three spines without penicillum (Coiffait1950 b:Fig.11;1955). But inAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeEskualdunellagenusEskualdunella one of the spines is longer and more robust than the two others.

tax:figure.tax:p: FIGURES 5–6. Inner sac of aedeagus of Leptodirini. 5—AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiadeliotispeciesBaronniesia delioti gen. n. sp. n. and 6—AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharisquerilhacidisparsubspeciesAbeilleAntrocharis querilhaci dispar Abeille de Perrin. BDAM, dorsal sacs of apex of median area; BRA, reinforcement bands; FDM, dorsal feather-like structures; FVM, ventral feather-like structures; NL, connection nodule; FAPY, apical fibers of PY; IVP, inverted “V” feather-like structures; PY, “piece en Y ”.

tax:ref_group.tax:p: In the genusAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBathysciolagenusJeannel, 1910BathysciolaJeannel,1910, the species ofovata group (Perreau2000,Fresneda & Salgado2006) have the apex of the stylus with only three spines, but the mesoventral keel is extended over the metaventrite, and transverse striae on the elytra are missing. Those characters separate theovata group from theAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharisgenusAntrocharis group andAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiagenusBaronniesia. The species ofmadoni andzariquieyi groups are closely related toovata group (Fresnedaet al.2007), and have a variable number of spines in the lateral stylus of the aedeagus (between5 and14). In the phylogenetic reconstruction byFresnedaet al. (2007) these groups ofAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBathysciolagenusBathysciola are not closely related to theAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharisgenusAntrocharis group.The other PyreneanAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBathysciolagenusBathysciola (lapidicola,meridionalis,larcennei andschiodtei groups) have four spines in the apex of the lateral stylus of the aedeagus (the only exception is one species of themeridionalis group,AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBathysciolafinismillenniispeciesFresneda & Salgado, 2006B. finismillenniiFresneda & Salgado,2006 with nine spines), and belong to a clade of Leptodirini restricted to the Spanish Basque country (seeFresnedaet al.2007):AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeJosettekiagenusBelles & Deliot, 1983JosettekiaBellés & Déliot,1983,AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeSpeocharidiusgenusJeannel, 1919SpeocharidiusJeannel,1919,AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeEuryspeonomusgenusJeannel, 1919EuryspeonomusJeannel,1919 (all with four spines) andAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAranzadiellagenusEspanol, 1972AranzadiellaEspañol,1972 (with about thirty spines).

tax:div.tax:p: In all other Pyrenean Leptodirini the number of spines in the apex of the lateral stylus of the aedeagus varies from two to five, but they all have a penicillum, which could be inserted in a depression or not, or be inserted on a membranous lamina.

tax:figure.tax:p: FIGURES 7–14. Apices of lateral styles of aedeagus of Leptodirini. 7—AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiadeliotispeciesBaronniesia delioti gen. n. sp. n.; 8—AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeParatroglophyesjeannelispeciesCoiffaitParatroglophyes jeanneli Coiffait; 9—AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesaubryiaubryisubspeciesCoiffaitTroglophyes aubryi aubryi Coiffait; 10—AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesgavoyispeciesAbeilleTroglophyes gavoyi Abeille de Perrin; 11—AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeParvospeonomusdelarouzeeispeciesFairmaireParvospeonomus delarouzeei Fairmaire; 12—AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaePhacomorphusPhacomorphoidessioberisioberisubspeciesCoiffaitPhacomorphus (Phacomorphoides)sioberi sioberi (Coiffait); 13—AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeSpeonomuscurvipessubcurvipessubspeciesAbeilleSpeonomus curvipes subcurvipes Abeille de Perrin; 14—AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeParaspeonomusvandelispeciesCoiffait.Paraspeonomus vandeli Coiffait.

tax:div.tax:p: There are two maintypes of lateral stylus of the aedeagus among the rest of Pyrenean Leptodirini:

1) TheAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesgenusTroglophyestype. The apex of the lateral stylus of the aedeagus with two or (more frequently) three long spines, with a dense penicillum formed by numerous short setae. This penicillum may be inserted in a cavity or directly on the integument of the apex of the stylus (Figs.10–12). In thespeluncarum group ofAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeSpeonomusgenusJeannel, 1908SpeonomusJeannel,1908 the third spine is often concealed by the penicillum. The following groups have the lateral stylus of theAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesgenusTroglophyestype:AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBathysciellagenusJeannel, 1906BathysciellaJeannel,1906;AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBellesiagenusFresneda & Hernando, 1994Bellesia Fresneda & Hernando,1994;AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeCeretophyesgenusFresneda, 1998CeretophyesFresneda,1998;speluncarum (Jeannel,1947) andAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeSpeonomusehlersispeciesPerreau, 2000ehlersi (Perreau,2000) groups, and the subgenusAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeMachaeroscelisgenusJeannel, 1924MachaeroscelisJeannel,1924 ofAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeSpeonomusgenusSpeonomus;AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaePhacomorphusgenusJeannel, 1908PhacomorphusJeannel,1908, including the subgenusAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaePhacomorphoidesgenusDupre, 1989PhacomorphoidesDupré,1989 (Fig.12);AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeParvospeonomusgenusBelles & Escola, 1977ParvospeonomusBellés & Escolà,1977 (Fig.11);AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaePerriniellagenusJeannel, 1910PerriniellaJeannel,1910 andAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesgenusAbeilleTroglophyes Abeille de Perrin,1894 (Fig.10).AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesgenusTroglophyes is a para- or polyphyletic genus (Fresnedaet al.2007). All the easternmost species ofAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesgenusTroglophyes,AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesbedelispeciesJeannel, 1906T. bedeliJeannel,1906,T. g.AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesgavoyispeciesAbeillegavoyi Abeille de Perrin,1894,T. g. alluaudiJeannel,1911,AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesludovicispeciesChobaut, 1903T. ludoviciChobaut,1903 andAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesoblongulusspeciesReitter, 1908T. oblongulusReitter,1908, are closely related toAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeCeretophyesgenusFresneda, 1998CeretophyesFresneda,1998 andAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaePerriniellagenusJeannel, 1910PerriniellaJeannel,1910, unlike theAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharisgenusAntrocharis group of genera andAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesaubryiaubryisubspeciesT. a. aubryi andT. a. vallierensis of the central Pyrenees.

2) TheAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTrocharanisgenusTrocharanistype. The apex of the lateral stylus of the aedeagus is with three long spines (sometimes five). One can be longer than the other two (Fig.13:AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeSpeonomuscurvipessubcurvipessubspeciesSpeonomus curvipes subcurvipes (Abeille de Perrin,1878)), or two longer than the third one, all three of different size (Fig.14:AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeParaspeonomusvandelispeciesCoiffait, 1952Paraspeonomus vandeliCoiffait,1952) or all subequal. A dense penicillum formed by numerous long setae inserted on the side or on a more or less developed membranous lamina is always present; in some species the long setae of the penicillum look like a pedunculus or thin extension of the membranous lamina (e.g. inAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeSpeonomuscarrereispeciesFoures, 1954S. carrereiFourès,1954). This group is formed by the genusAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeParaspeonomusgenusCoiffait, 1952ParaspeonomusCoiffait,1952,AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeSpeonomusgenusSpeonomus ofpyreneus andzophosinus groups (Jeannel1947), subgenusAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeMetaspeonomusgenusCoiffait, 1959MetaspeonomusCoiffait,1959 andAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTrocharanisgenusReitter, 1885TrocharanisReitter,1885. All the genera of the southern side of central Pyrenees and coastal ridges of Catalonia (Spain) belong to this group:AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeLagariellagenusFresneda, 2000Lagariella Fresneda,2000,AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeNaspuniusgenusFresneda, Hernando & Lagar, 1994NaspuniusFresneda, Hernando & Lagar,1994,AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaePallaresiellagenusFresneda, 1998PallaresiellaFresneda,1998,AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeSalgadoiagenusFresneda, 1998SalgadoiaFresneda,1998,AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeSpeonomitesgenusJeannel, 1910SpeonomitesJeannel,1910,AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeStygiophyesgenusFresneda, 1998StygiophyesFresneda,1998,AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTrapezodirusgenusJeannel, 1924TrapezodirusJeannel,1924 andAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglocharinusgenusReitter, 1908TroglocharinusReitter,1908 (except the three taxa of the subgenusAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharidiusgenusJeannel, 1910AntrocharidiusJeannel,1910 with a secondary loss of penicillum but with the membranous lamina).

Dilated antennae in male ofAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiagenusBaronniesia is a character shared withAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeJosettekiaangelinaespeciesBelles & Deliot, 1983Josettekia angelinaeBellés & Déliot,1983 andAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeParaspeonomusvandelispeciesCoiffait, 1952Paraspeonomus vandeliCoiffait,1952.AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeJosettekiaangelinaespeciesJosettekia angelinae has the9 th (especially) and10 th male antennomeres dilated. However, inAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeJosettekiagenusJosettekia this is not a generic character, as the second species of the genus,AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeJosettekiamendizabalispeciesBolivar, 1921J. mendizabali (Bolívar,1921), does not show any dilatation of the male antennae. Both species ofAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeJosettekiagenusJosettekia have the apex of the lateral stylus with four short spines and lack the two inverted “V” feather-like structures in the inner sac of aedeagus. InAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeParaspeonomusvandelispeciesP. vandeli only the fourth antennal article of male is dilated, but the lateral stylus of the aedeagus has a membranous lamina and a penicillum, and the inner sac lacks the two inverted “V” feather-like structures.

Phylogenetic analyses.AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiagenusBaronniesia gen. n. and the genusAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeGesciellagenusGesciella (omitted from the previous analyses) were added to the data matrix ofFresnedaet al.2007 (Appendix1: this paper) with the aim of including both genera in a formal phylogenetic analysis. SeeFresnedaet al.2007:335–344 for the list of the34 characters and their states. For a list of studied species see Appendix1 inFresnedaet al.2007. For composition of groups of terminal taxa sharing identical character states and lumped together for the purposes of analysis see Appendix2 in this paper. Despite the fact that three new characters were added to the matrix ofFresnedaet al. (2007) (see below), this could not help to resolve relationships betweenAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiagenusBaronniesia and the most closely related taxa (theAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharisgenusAntrocharis group). In the new character matrix (Appendix1)AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiagenusBaronniesia shares all character states withAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharisgenusAntrocharis,AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeGesciellagenusGesciella,AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeParatroglophyesgenusParatroglophyes andAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeTroglophyesgenusTroglophyes.

Character35.Lateral styles of aedeagus: very thin along their entire length (0) and always shorter than the median lobe (Figs.3–4); or strong along their entire length (1), with the apex more or less thickened and of length ranging from shorter to longer than the median lobe. Coded as missing data (?) for the species with character states26 (1),27 (1),28 (0),29 (0),30 (1) and31 (1),sensuFresnedaet al. (2007). These species have the apex of the lateral stylus of the aedeagus with two to five spines; when they have three, there is always a penicillum, cavity or membranous lamina.

Character36.Apical part of the median region of the inner sac of aedeagus: with two very sclerotized pieces forming an inverted “V” located above FDM and FVM (Fig.5: IVP) (1); without inverted “V”, or with other structures (0). In the species with the inner sac of the aedeagus lacking copulating armature (Fresnedaet al.2007: character16, state 0) character36 was coded as missing data (?).

Character37.Basal region of inner sac of aedeagus: apical piece of PY (FAPY) above the connection nodule (NL) very thin and elongated (Fig.5:FAPY) (1) or short and conical (0). In species without PY (Fresnedaet al.2007: character17, state 0) character37 was coded as missing data (?).

The extended data matrix was analysed using the same methods as inFresnedaet al. (2007): the shortest trees were heuristically searched inPAUP 4.0b10 (Swofford2002) with10,000 tree-bisection-reconnection (TBR) replicas, swapping on all multiple starting trees, and saving all of them. To obtain a higher resolution, data were reweighted successively according to the rescaled consistency index (Swofford,2002), and a heuristic search conducted on the initial set of the shortest trees (seeFresnedaet al.2007 for details).

The topology of the strict consensus of the330 reweighted trees (consistency index 0.67, retention index 0.9) was identical to that ofFresnedaet al. (2007) (Fig.17) and, thus, was not affected by addition of three new characters.AnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeGesciellagenusGesciella andAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeBaronniesiagenusBaronniesia appear in the same polytomy with the remaining genera of theAnimaliaInsectaColeopteraLeiodidaeAntrocharisgenusAntrocharis group, as they share all character states.
